texts.name: Fierabras - Vulgate Version (c. 1200)
texts.shelfmark: Leuven, Universiteitsbibliotheek, MS G.170, ff. 53-130 (Firmin Didot)
texts.adaptation: Anglo-Norman adaptation of the continental French Vulgate Fierabras ('version longue'). Fragment.

texts.name: Fierabras - Vulgate Version (c. 1200)
texts.shelfmark: Hanover, Niedersächsische Landesbibliothek, Ms IV 578, ff. 25r-100v
texts.adaptation: Anglo-Norman adaptation of the continental French Vulgate Fierabras ('version longue'), somewhat abridged. Incomplete (two folios of the MS are missing).
texts.fragment: incomplete (two folios of the MS are missing)

texts.name: Sir Ferumbras (s. XIV <sup>ex</sup>)
texts.adaptation: Middle English translation of the French Vulgate text of Fierabras. Incomplete.

texts.name: Firumbras (s. XIV <sup>4</sup>)
texts.shelfmark: London, British Library, MS Additional 37492 (Fillingham Manuscript), ff. 1r-30r
texts.adaptation: Middle English translation of the French Vulgate text of Fierabras. Incomplete.

texts.name: Fierabras - 'version courte' (c. 1300)
texts.adaptation: Anglo-Norman adaptation of Fierabras. Heavily abbreviated.
texts.integrated: La Destruction de Rome functions as a prequel to Fierabras in this manuscript arrangement.

texts.name: The Sowdowne of Babylone (s. XIV <sup>ex</sup> - XV <sup>in</sup>)
texts.adaptation: English  verse text translated from Anglo-Norman 'version courte' of Fierabras and La Destruction de Rome. Incomplete.
texts.integrated: Combines the Fierabras narrative with material from La Destruction de Rome

texts.name: Gesta Karoli Magni [Fierabras] (s. XV <sup>1</sup>)
texts.compilationPlace: Ireland: South West Midlands, ?Ennis, Nenagh or Limerick.
texts.shelfmark: Dublin, Trinity College MS 667 (previously MS F 5 3), pp. 85-100
texts.adaptation: Latin prose translation of the French chanson de geste, Fierabras. Incomplete.

texts.name: Stair Fortibrais (s. XV <sup>1</sup>)
texts.adaptation: Irish prose translation from a Latin version of the narrative similar to that now preserved in Trinity College Dublin MS 667. This in turn is from the French chanson de geste. Incomplete.
texts.integrated: In Irish translation, this text opens with a short account of the finding of the True Cross, derived from a Latin account De Inventione Sanctae Crucis. This features in all copies of Stair Fortibrais where the opening of the text survives.
